title: Does the truth resist simplicity? - Quora

response.answer_text: To de Broglie, Einstein revealed an instinctive reason for his inability to accept the purely statistical interpretation of wave mechanics. It was a reason which linked him with Rutherford, who used to state that "it should be possible to explain the laws of physics to a barmaid." Einstein, having a final discussion with de Broglie on the platform of the Gare du Nord in Paris, whence they had traveled from Brussels to attend the Fresnel centenary celebrations, said "that all physical theories, their mathematical expressions apart ought to lend themselves to so simple a description 'that even a child could understand them.' " Emphasis is mine and not from the original text. — Clark, Ronald W. "Einstein: the life and times." American Journal of Physics 41.8 (1973): 1029-1032. Complexity and simpleness are not contradictory concepts. They are in fact reliant on each other. Truth resists both superfluous complexity and simplicity. If you say the truth, resists simpleness, then I strongly disagree with you. If you say the truth resists, simplicity, then I agree. Einstein’s equations undercut a vast array of data and phenomenon. But yet, his equations are relatively simple and accurately describe phenomenon. Look at the sheer length or more accurately, lack thereof, of the equation: [math]E=MC²[/math] It contains literally five characters. Now consider the sheer vastness and implications Mass-Energy Equivalence holds! Given that Occam’s razor holds status in logical, analytical, and scientific thought, we should reconsider the presupposition of the question. Solomonoff Prediction and Occam's Razor An example of a phenomenon where simpleness generates deep, vast, and complex phenomenon is that of a fractal. A simple equation can generate vast and infinite complexity. Occam's razor - Wikipedia
